text: very late to this particular party, but partying early morning at the airport (aka catching up on a billion emails and slack). Just want to say how great the Magnum deck reads/looks. Very very nice work all. Excited to be back in office next week, if only to see it all happen in real life. Guessing it will all hit extremely well at Magnum HQ.
<!channel>: good news, magnum is going to try to get us feedback before 6/23 next week.
on the ux preview, that is.
sweet
bad news is they have internal meetings 6/23-28 so it's looking like they won't get visual design feedback until 7/1, but we've planned for that.
<!channel>: i'm about to send magnum's contract out, but i'd love for you to take a look at the supported device and browser list and let me know if you have any concerns. cool?

Nexus 6 (5.0)
Samsung Galaxy S6 (5.0)
HTC One M9 (5.0)
LG G3 (4.4)

Samsung Galaxy S3 (4.1)
HTC DNA (4.1)
Motorola RAZR HD (4.1)
TABLETS
Samsung Galaxy Tab 4 - 10inch (4.4)
Samsung Galaxy Tab 4 - 7inch (4.4)

ASUS Nexus 7inch Tab (4.3)


*iOS*
iPhone 6
iPhone 6+
iPhone 5s
iPhone 5
iPad 2 and up

*Supported browsers*
Chrome current version (45) plus four previous versions
Firefox (38) plus four previous versions
Internet Explorer 10 and up ( *Gaston thinks we might want to support IE 9 and up based on this link <http://www.w3schools.com/browsers/browsers_explorer.asp>, thoughts?)
Safari 7.1 and up

text: <@U04JZANJF> I think my note about Android was to replace the entire list with “Chrome on Android."
i’d go with gaston’s recommendation… <@U02618EV1> are there any real big performance gaps between 9 and 10?
<@U02618EV1>, i'll make that change!
<@U0260V1BX> I don’t know.
<http://www.w3schools.com/cssref/css3_browsersupport.asp>
<@U0260V1BX> <http://caniuse.com/#compare=ie+9,ie+10> for features but I don’t know much about performance for the specific browsers.

<@U0260V1BX|melissa> uploaded a file: <https://uncorked.slack.com/files/melissa/F06H3RUTU/screen_shot_2015-06-18_at_11.20.06_am.png|Screen Shot 2015-06-18 at 11.20.06 AM.png> and commented: well i guess we should take this into consideration

initial_comment.comment: well i guess we should take this into consideration

text: If we say chrome on android we should definitely specify which versions of Android we're supporting. simply saying chrome on android means we're supporting all android hardware
That’s right. But those are devices not browsers. The same way we don’t specify Mac vs PC, or Macbook pro vs air.
Right, but we specify which ios devices we support in the same way, those will be running the safari browser
I don't think we should have any contract that implies we support all Android hardware. More specification is better, so we can even say x devices, and x browsers.
Keep in mind there are 18,796 android deviceas
iOS is different because you can only have a couple of very similar browser versions for every iOS release. With android you could have a very old device using the latest browser release.
One thing we could do is to look at what we said on other contracts: Trapit, SmallBatch, Vroom.
Totally understand, but what we're saying here is that these are the devices we're optimizing for.
Vroom contract specified exact android devices

All I'm saying is that it may work on very old devices, but these are the ones that we should be on the hook for in terms of bug fixing. We should not be on the hook for fixing bugs as they're soon on a super old android that has a totally different screen size.
I just had a quick chat with Abby. Looks like the original list posted by Amanda makes the most sense for a contractual standpoint. Let’s use that.

so - im a little out of my element here - but one thing I’ll add that might or might not be of interest: when I was in both dubai and tanzania - the people who were using smart phones were all on crazy Chinese brands I’d never seen
so it might be nice to list specifics - which, seeing Gastons message, it sounds like we will
so never mind
Specifics are just for contractual clarity. We'll be optimizing for the listed devices but will totally end up supporting lots more.
